newsitem.title: FRANCE: France defends Corsica policy, bars independence.
newsitem.headline: France defends Corsica policy, bars independence.

text.p: France insisted on Tuesday that its crackdown on separatist violence in Corsica was showing results and flatly ruled out independence for the Mediterranean island following a nationalist bomb attack on the Bordeaux city hall.

"Sooner or later those responsible for these attacks will be identified, questioned and arrested, and for many of these attacks we are not far from concluding our investigations," Interior Minister Jean-Louis Debre said in a broadcast interview.
Asked if the government ruled out offering Corsica its independence from mainland France one day, Debre responded: "Totally".

The interview on Europe 1 radio took place a day after separatists claimed responsibility for a bomb attack on Prime Minister Alain Juppe's mayoral office in Bordeaux and an angry government vowed to put the guerrillas out of action.
The government vow has been greeted with some skepticism as bombings have continued at a steady pace despite earlier pledges to end violence on the sunny resort island.
But Debre insisted that the government policy was already working. Since January, 22 individuals implicated in separatist attacks had been imprisoned and were still in jail, he said.
He also ruled out a resumption of negotiations with nationalist representatives until calm was restored.
The "historic wing" of the outlawed Corsican National Liberation Front (FLNC) asserted responsibility on Monday for Saturday night's bombing of the Bordeaux city hall.
The attack, a clear escalation of the group's long-running low-intensity struggle for greater autonomy from Paris, raised the spectre of a guerrilla offensive in mainland France.
The FLNC has accused Juppe of going back on pledges made in secret peace talks earlier this year when he ordered a crackdown on separatist gunmen in July.
